elements.title: Progressive Price Disclosure Matched to Guest's Decision Tree
elements.problem: Tamycka's decision tree is: Price first -> Location second -> Child safety third -> Everything else. The current listing page information hierarchy does not match this tree. The listing page leads with photos, location, and amenities, then shows nightly rate, then calculates total only at proposal time. For a guest whose first filter is 'Can I afford this?', the current information order forces her to invest cognitive effort in irrelevant details before she gets the answer to her primary question. Cialdini's commitment research warns that if the full price is revealed only after the guest has mentally committed (configured days, imagined herself in the space), any price surprise triggers the lowball perception. The information architecture must reveal price progressively but completely before any commitment action.
elements.solution: Restructure the information hierarchy across three surfaces to match the budget guest's decision tree: (1) Search Results Card: Lead with total estimated cost for the guest's configured schedule (e.g., '$225/week for Thu-Fri-Sat'), not per-night rate. Show per-night rate as secondary context. Include a small badge for child-safety verification if applicable. This answers Tamycka's primary question ('Can I afford this?') before she clicks. (2) Listing Page: Open with a price calculator panel that updates live as the guest configures days and duration. Show the total, the per-night rate, and any bulk discounts earned. Below the calculator, show photos and space details. Below that, safety features and host info. Below that, reviews from similar guests. The scan order mirrors the decision tree. (3) Proposal Summary: Before submission, show a full price breakdown with all fees, explicitly compared to the per-night rate she saw in search. No new information should appear here. This is a confirmation of what she already knows, not a reveal.

evidence.quote: for me, it's more a price than it is location
evidence.insight: The guest's own words define her information hierarchy. Price is the primary filter. Any information architecture that buries price behind location, photos, or amenities is structurally misaligned with this guest's needs.

evidence.quote: Its only purpose is to cause a prospect to decide to buy one of the dealership's cars. Once the decision is made...the dealer never intends it to go through.
evidence.insight: The lowball works by revealing the true cost after commitment. The antidote is progressive disclosure that reveals full cost BEFORE commitment, at each escalation step.

evidence.quote: We go anywhere between $50 a night and it goes pretty high...I think we could get you under $75 a night.
evidence.insight: Igor discloses the price range immediately and then narrows it based on Tamycka's specific needs. The platform must replicate this: broad range on search, specific estimate on listing, exact price on proposal.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Total cost for configured schedule. Secondary: Per-night rate and bulk discount. Tertiary: Location and safety. Quaternary: Photos, amenities, host info. The guest should be able to answer 'Can I afford this?' within 2 seconds of viewing any surface.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Progressive narrowing: Search shows estimated range -> Listing shows exact calculation with live updates -> Proposal shows final confirmed price. Each step narrows the range but never introduces a new cost that was not visible in the prior step.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 price numbers visible at once (per-night rate, total for configured stay, savings vs. nightly booking). Any additional pricing information (cleaning fees, platform fees, taxes) should be expandable but not default-visible if they are included in the displayed total.
scan_order: Per-night rate with bulk discount indicator
exclude: Host biography on search results (not decision-relevant for budget guests)
Amenity lists on search results (Tamycka needs only fridge/microwave; full amenity list is listing-page content)
Cancellation policy on search results (relevant only after commitment intent is formed)

elements.title: Similar-Other Social Proof Placement in Information Hierarchy
elements.problem: The current listing page, if it shows reviews or social proof at all, treats them as a separate section at the bottom of the page -- below the fold, after photos, amenities, and rules. For a guest like Tamycka, who is uncertain about child safety and platform legitimacy, social proof from similar others is not supplementary information -- it is primary decision-making data. Cialdini: 'when we are unsure of ourselves...we are most likely to look to and accept the actions of others as correct' (Ch. 4). Placing social proof below the fold means the guest must invest significant scrolling and reading before reaching the information that would most effectively resolve her uncertainty. Many guests will drop off before they get there. The information architecture fails to serve the uncertainty-resolution function that social proof provides.
elements.solution: Integrate social proof into the primary information hierarchy at three strategic points: (1) Listing Page Header Zone: Immediately below the listing title/price, show a compact social proof line: '4 recurring guests | 2 families with children | Avg. stay: 8 weeks.' This is not a review section; it is a trust signal placed at the point of first uncertainty. (2) Safety Context: Adjacent to the child-safety/family-friendly badge, show the most relevant similar-other quote: 'A mother of two said: Clean, safe, perfect for my Thursday routine.' This resolves the specific safety uncertainty Tamycka has. (3) Proposal Confidence Zone: On the proposal creation page, just above the submit button, show a reinforcing social proof line: 'Guests who book 3 nights/week save 28% vs. nightly rates. 15 guests have this schedule.' This normalizes the action she is about to take. In all three cases, the social proof must be (a) specific to the guest's situation (parent, recurring, budget), (b) compact (one line or badge, not a review section), and (c) placed at the moment of uncertainty, not after it.

evidence.quote: one means we use to determine what is correct is to find out what other people think is correct. The principle applies especially to the way we decide what constitutes correct behavior.
evidence.insight: Social proof is not supplementary -- it is a primary decision input for uncertain guests. Its placement in the information hierarchy must reflect its functional importance.

evidence.quote: a lot of people don't feel the need to do that [trial night]. They're sort of comfortable with other home sharing companies.
evidence.insight: Igor uses verbal social proof at the exact moment of commitment hesitation. The platform must place written social proof at the same moment: adjacent to the commitment action, not in a separate section.

evidence.quote: nursery-school-age children chosen because they were terrified of dogs merely watched a little boy playing happily with a dog for twenty minutes a day...67 percent of them were willing to climb into a playpen with a dog.
evidence.insight: Seeing a similar other succeed resolves fear. For Tamycka, seeing that another parent with young children thrived in a listing resolves her safety fears more effectively than any feature description.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Social proof from similar others is primary information for uncertain guests. It should appear alongside or immediately after the primary decision data (price, safety), not in a separate reviews section below the fold.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Compact social proof (one-line badges) at each uncertainty gate. Expanded reviews available on tap/click for guests who want more detail. Never force expanded reviews on the primary scan.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 social proof line per context zone. Each line should contain no more than 2 data points ('3 families with children | Average stay: 8 weeks'). Do not show star ratings alone without context (4.5 stars means nothing without 'rated by 8 recurring guests').
scan_order: Compact social proof badge in header zone (guest count, family count, average stay length)
Specific similar-other quote adjacent to safety badge
Reinforcing social proof line above proposal submit button
exclude: Generic star ratings without context ('4.5 stars' alone)
Review content from dissimilar guests (corporate travelers reviewing a family-friendly space)
Social proof numbers that are too small to be credible (do not show '1 family stayed here' -- wait for 3+)

elements.title: Process Explainer as Uncertainty Reducer for First-Time Guests
elements.problem: Tamycka asked multiple process questions in the call: 'how does that process work? Like, do I send money? And then there's a lockbox and then I have a security code?' (10:07-10:16), 'can I also use the app?' (14:33-14:39), 'are you doing what the app does?' (16:09-16:13). These questions reveal deep uncertainty about the operational process of Split Lease. For a first-time user, the platform's novel model (shared-space, recurring nights, lockbox access, host negotiation) is unlike any prior experience. Cialdini's social proof research on pluralistic ignorance shows that when people are uncertain about how to behave, they look to others for guidance. But on the platform, there are no visible 'others' showing how the process works. The guest must either figure it out alone (high cognitive load) or call Igor (defeating the platform's purpose). The information architecture must proactively answer the process questions Tamycka asked verbally.
elements.solution: Create a contextual process explainer that appears at three strategic moments: (1) Discovery/First Visit: A compact 'How It Works' module showing the 4-step guest journey (Browse -> Propose -> Agree -> Stay) with a single line for each step. This should be visible on the homepage without scrolling. Frame it as social proof: 'Here is how 200+ guests found their recurring NYC stay.' (2) Listing Page: Before the 'Create Proposal' button, show a 3-step micro-explainer of what happens next: 'You configure your preferred days -> You submit a proposal -> The host responds within 48 hours.' This removes the uncertainty Tamycka expressed at 10:07. (3) Proposal Creation: As the guest configures days and duration, show contextual tooltips explaining each choice: 'Choosing 30+ nights unlocks bulk pricing' (addresses her 05:09 question), 'Your first payment is by credit card' (addresses the payment process from the call). Each explainer should be compact (under 50 words per context), contextual (appears where the question arises), and social-proof-enhanced ('Most guests complete this in under 3 minutes').

evidence.quote: how does that process work? Like, do I send money? And then there's a lockbox and then I have a security code, like, is that how it works?
evidence.insight: Three distinct process questions in one sentence. The guest is uncertain about payment method, access mechanism, and operational flow. The platform must answer all three preemptively.

evidence.quote: are you doing what the app does? So if they don't want to pay for your services, they would use the app.
evidence.insight: Tamycka is trying to understand the platform's self-service capability. She needs to know that the platform can guide her through the process without human intervention.

evidence.quote: Be as precise as possible about your need for aid. Do not allow bystanders to come to their own conclusions because...the principle of social proof and the consequent pluralistic ignorance effect might well cause them to view your situation as a nonemergency.
evidence.insight: The platform must not leave process questions unanswered, hoping the guest will figure it out. Unanswered questions trigger pluralistic ignorance: 'If no one else is asking, maybe I am the one who does not understand.' The guest leaves rather than looking foolish.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Process explanation is secondary to price and safety information but must appear BEFORE any commitment action. The guest must understand what she is committing to before she commits.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Contextual micro-explainers at the point of action, not a separate 'How It Works' page. Each explainer should be under 50 words and visually distinct from content (e.g., a light background callout). Expanded details available on tap for guests who need more.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 4 steps shown at once in any process overview. Each step described in 10 words or fewer. No jargon ('proposal' is acceptable; 'medium-term booking configuration' is not).
scan_order: 3-step next-actions explainer on listing page above Create Proposal button
exclude: Full FAQ content in the primary journey flow (belongs in help section)
Legal terminology in process explainers (lease terms belong in the document, not the explainer)
Process steps that the guest has already completed (show current + next steps only)

elements.title: Stay Timeline as Commitment Evidence Dashboard
elements.problem: During the active lease, the guest's Leases page currently shows payment schedules and date management. What it does not show is the guest's own commitment history: how many stays completed, reviews written, cleaning photos submitted, date changes requested. Cialdini's written commitment research (Ch. 3) demonstrates that physical evidence of prior actions is one of the strongest commitment-maintenance mechanisms: 'it provides physical evidence that the act occurred. Once a man wrote what the Chinese wanted, it was very difficult for him to believe that he had not done so.' For a recurring guest like Tamycka, her stay history IS her commitment evidence. If the platform makes this evidence visible, scannable, and progressive (a timeline that grows with each stay), it reinforces her identity as a committed, invested guest. Without this visibility, each weekly visit feels isolated rather than part of a building pattern.
elements.solution: Add a Stay Timeline to the active lease view that surfaces the guest's commitment history as a growing visual narrative: (1) Timeline Entries: Each completed stay appears as a compact card showing date, rating (if given), and cleaning photo status. The timeline grows downward with each stay, creating a visible accumulation of commitment evidence. (2) Summary Stats: At the top of the timeline, show aggregate metrics: 'Completed stays: 12 | Your average rating: 4.7 | Host's rating of you: 4.9 | Cleaning photos: 11/12.' These are Cialdini's 'physical evidence' made scannable. (3) Milestone Markers: At stay 5, 10, 20, show a milestone badge: 'You have completed 10 stays at this space -- you are among our most committed recurring guests.' This is a public commitment reinforcement that shifts self-image. (4) Social Context: Show how the guest's engagement compares to similar guests: 'You review more consistently than 80% of recurring guests.' This uses social proof to reinforce commitment behavior. The timeline should be the first thing the guest sees when opening the Leases page, before payment schedule or date management.

evidence.quote: a written declaration has some great advantages. First, it provides physical evidence that the act occurred.
evidence.insight: The stay timeline IS the physical evidence. Making it visible and growing creates an ever-strengthening commitment anchor.

evidence.quote: one of the things that people do is they'll leave stuff for their kids...he leaves toys, his daughter's toys at the location. And basically...we can also ensure that or guarantee that nobody touches those.
evidence.insight: Physical investment in the space (toys) is one form of commitment evidence. Digital investment (stay history, reviews, cleaning photos) is another. Both should be visible to the guest.

evidence.quote: persons who go through a great deal of trouble or pain to attain something tend to value it more highly than persons who attain the same thing with a minimum of effort.
evidence.insight: The timeline makes accumulated effort visible. A guest who can see 12 completed stays, 10 reviews, and 11 cleaning photos recognizes her own investment and values the arrangement more.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Stay count and current streak. Secondary: Aggregate ratings and engagement stats. Tertiary: Individual stay cards with details. The guest should see her commitment evidence before she sees her payment schedule.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Summary stats always visible at top of Leases page. Individual stay cards expand on tap. Milestone badges appear inline at natural breakpoints (5, 10, 20 stays).
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Summary stats limited to 4 numbers. Timeline cards limited to 3 data points each (date, rating, photo status). Milestone messages limited to 1 sentence.
scan_order: Summary stats bar (stays completed, average rating, engagement score)
exclude: Payment amounts on timeline cards (payment is a separate concern from stay history)
Host messages in the timeline (messages belong in the communication channel, not the commitment dashboard)
Negative data points (missed cleaning photos should be absent, not highlighted as failures)
